The LOCO-I compression scheme is made of a limited set of operations that execute sequentially on pixel values [4].
As described in [4], LOCO-I updates the context parameters at each pixel coding/decoding phases.
The reason stems from the fact that LOCO-I allows three modalities for the compression of color images, namely plane-interleaved, line-interleaved, and sample-interleaved [4].
The particular modality, that can be freely chosen at the application level, determines the entering condition for the so called run mode [4].
As explained in [4], the context is made only of four pixels that we name \$NW,\$ \$N,\$ \$NE\$ and \$W\$.

context.text: Recently, determining the minimal stopping distance for an arbitrary binary linear code has been shown to be an NP-complete problem [23].

Although not explicitly stated in [23], it follows that the task of determining the minimal stopping distance for LDPC codes with sparse parity matrices is still NP-complete regardless of the sparsity constraint on the codes of interest.

Nonetheless, in [23], the NP-completeness of \${\hbox{SD}}({\mbi H},t)\$ is proven by reduction from the classic NP-complete VERTEX-COVER problem to \${\hbox{SD}}({\mbi H},t)\$ in a way that any vertex cover for the original graph \$G=(V,E)\$ is mapped bijectively to a stopping set for \${\mbi H}\$.

By carefully inspecting the construction of \${\mbi H}\$ from \$G\$ in [23], we notice that there are \$\vert E\vert +\vert V\vert (\vert E\vert +1)\$ rows and \$2\vert E\vert -1+\vert V\vert \vert E\vert\$ columns in \${\mbi H}\$ and there are \$2\vert E\vert \vert V\vert +3\vert E\vert\$ nonzero entries in \${\mbi H}\$.
As a result, the same reduction proposed in [23] can be used to prove that \${\hbox{SD}}({\mbi H}_{\rm sparse},t)\$ is an NP-complete problem regardless of such a sparsity constraint.

context.text: In this paper, we study the following problem of high-dimensional inference with sparsity constraints: given noisy linear observations of an unknown vector \${\beta ^{\ast}}\$, how to recover the positions of its nonzero entries, otherwise known as its sparsity pattern or support set? This problem, known variously as sparsity recovery, support recovery, or variable selection, arises in a broad variety of contexts, including subset selection in regression [28], compressed sensing [4], [9], structure estimation in graphical models [27], sparse approximation [8], and signal denoising [6].

Most closely related to the current paper—as we discuss in more detail in the sequel—are results by Donoho [10], as well as Candes and Tao [4] that provide high probability results for random ensembles.

More specifically, as we discuss in more detail in Section IV-B, in the special case of linear sparsity (i.e., \${k}/ {p}\rightarrow \alpha\$ for some \$\alpha > 0\$), this theorem provides a noisy analog of results previously established for basis pursuit in the noiseless case [4], [10], [13].

Previous work by Donoho [10], as well as Candes and Tao [4] has focused on the special case of the uniform Gaussian ensemble (i.e., \$X_{ij} \sim N(0, 1)\$, i.i.d.). in the noiseless \$(\sigma ^{2} = 0)\$ and underdetermined setting \$({n}\ll{p})\$.

When the amount of data \${n}\$ scales only linearly with ambient dimension \${p}\$, then the presence of noise means that the recoverable support size drops from a linear fraction (i.e., \${k}= \nu {p}\$ as in the work [4], [10]) to a sublinear fraction (i.e., \${k}= {\cal O}\left({{p}\over {\log {p}}}\right)\$, as in Corollary 2).

context.text: In this paper, we study the following problem of high-dimensional inference with sparsity constraints: given noisy linear observations of an unknown vector \${\beta ^{\ast}}\$, how to recover the positions of its nonzero entries, otherwise known as its sparsity pattern or support set? Also related to the current paper is recent work on the use of the Lasso for model selection, both for random designs by Meinshausen and Buhlmann [27] and deterministic designs by Zhao and Yu [37].

Moreover, our result can also be adapted to an entirely different scaling regime, in which the sparsity index is sublinear \$({k}/ {p}\rightarrow 0)\$, as considered by a separate body of recent work [27], [37] on the high-dimensional Lasso.

Candès et al. [4] discuss using either a fixed \$\epsilon _{n}\$ or selecting it, while Foucart and Lai [11] argue that, at least in terms of the associated cost functions, letting \$\epsilon _{n} \rightarrow 0\$ converges to a solution for (4).

Although we have not explicitly considered it here, the RIP also plays a role in quantifying the robustness of \$\ell ^{p}\$ recovery to observation noise [3], [11], i.e., when \${\bf x}={\mmb{\Phi}} {\bf y} +\epsilon\$.

However, as noted here and in [11] exact recovery is independent of dictionary scaling, \${\mmb{\Phi}}\rightarrow c {\mmb{\Phi}}\$, while robustness to noise is directly related to the scale of the dictionary.

It is possible to define the error relative to the isometry constants as in [11], however it could be argued that a fairer measure of robustness would be in terms of absolute error when the dictionary is also constrained to have some physically reasonable property.

context.text: The sum capacity of the \$K\$-user time-varying/frequency-selective interference channel (see Fig. 1) was approximated in [3] as  where \${\rm SNR}\$ represents the signal-to-noise ratio (the total transmit power of all nodes when the local noise power at each receiver is normalized to unity).
The achievable scheme for the capacity characterization of interference networks is based on the idea of interference alignment [3].

The interference alignment technique of [3] has been generalized in [4] to find a capacity approximation of wireless \$X\$ networks within \$o(\log ({\rm SNR}))\$. \$X\$ networks are a generalization of interference networks—unlike an interference network where each transmitter has a message for only its corresponding receiver, in an \$X\$ network every transmitter has an independent message for every receiver.

Neither the interference network considered in [3] nor the \$X\$ network considered in [4] allow any mechanism for the source nodes to cooperate among themselves by learning each other's messages or for the destination nodes to cooperate among themselves by sharing their received signals.

Since the results of [3] show that \$K/2\$ degrees of freedom can be achieved even without relays and cooperation, the conclusion is that relays and transmitter/receiver cooperation cannot increase the degrees of freedom of frequency-selective interference networks.

A second contribution of this work is to extend to converse of Theorem 1 and the interference alignment based achievable scheme of [3] to networks where every node can behave as both a source for some message and a destination for another message.
Achievability follows trivially from [3].

Neither the interference network considered in [3] nor the \$X\$ network considered in [4] allow any mechanism for the source nodes to cooperate among themselves by learning each other's messages or for the destination nodes to cooperate among themselves by sharing their received signals.
Thus, the achievability \${{SD}\over {S+D-1}}\$ degrees of freedom without relays, feedback, full-duplex operation, and cooperation follows trivially from [4].

Following the definition of an \$X\$ network [4], for all \$j\in \{1,2,\ldots, S\}\$ and for all \$i\in \{S+R+1,S+R+2,\ldots, S+R+D\}\$, there is an independent message \$W_{i, j}\$ to be communicated from source node \$j\$ to destination node \$i\$.

For the case of multiple servers and Bernoulli arrivals but with vector connectivity (i.e., each user is either connected to all servers or none) and the one-server-per-queue constraint, the LCQ policy (a more generalized multiqueue version of the LCQ policy in [3]) is optimal [4].
